Annotation 2: Front setback is 10' instead of 20'

Street side setback is 10' instead of 16'

visual_elements.description: A collection of seven diagrams (labeled A through G) illustrating setback rules for various oddly shaped lots. The diagrams are arranged in two rows. The top row shows a flag lot, a standard corner lot, and a substandard corner lot. The bottom row shows a through lot, a wedge-shaped lot, and two lots with more than four sides. Each diagram depicts the lot lines, adjacent streets, sidewalks, required setbacks, and the resulting buildable area (shaded gray). Annotations with arrows point to specific features to explain the rules for determining front, rear, and side yards and setback dimensions.
visual_elements.location: Center and bottom of the page

visual_elements.description: Figure A, labeled 'Flag lot'. It shows a lot behind another lot with a narrow strip of land connecting it to the street. It illustrates that the front setback is 10' instead of 20' and defines the front lot line as the one closest and most parallel to the street.
Figure B, labeled 'Corner lot'. It shows a standard rectangular lot at the intersection of two streets. It indicates a 'Street-side yard' with a 16' setback.

Figure C, labeled 'Substandard Corner lot w/frontage < 50''. It shows a smaller corner lot. Annotations explain that the front lot line is the shorter of the two frontages and the street side setback is reduced to 10' from 16'.
Figure D, labeled 'Through lot'. It shows a lot that spans between two parallel streets, with a front yard on one street and a rear yard on the other.

Figure E, labeled 'Wedge shaped lot'. It shows a lot on a curved street, resembling a slice of a pie. An annotation explains that the rear yard is determined by a 20' radius from the theoretical intersection of the side lot lines.
Figure F, labeled 'Lot with more than 4 sides'. It shows an irregular pentagonal lot. An annotation indicates the rear lot line is the one farthest and most parallel to the street.
Figure G, labeled 'Lot with more than 4 sides'. It shows an L-shaped lot. An annotation indicates the rear lot line is the one farthest and most parallel to the street.

A legend or 'Key' in the upper left quadrant that defines five visual symbols: a solid line for 'Curb', a dashed line for 'Lot line', a cross-hatched rectangle for 'Sidewalk', a thin solid line for 'Required setbacks', and a shaded rectangle for 'Buildable area'.

technical_specifications.parameter: Substandard corner lot street side setback
